questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126 mEq/L, AST: 62, ALT: 56, RBS: 112 mg/dL, and serum bilirubin of 0.8 mg%. Which of the following organisms is responsible? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient presenting with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, diarrhea, bilateral lung infiltrates, hyponatremia, and elevated liver enzymes, Legionella pneumonia should be strongly suspected.

questions.text: A woman presented with unilateral pulsatile headache, photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, which is exaggerated on skipping her meals. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Migraine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient presents with a unilateral, pulsatile headache accompanied by photophobia (sensitivity to light), phonophobia (sensitivity to sound), and nausea. These are classic features of a migraine.
  • • Additionally, the headache is exacerbated by skipping meals, a known trigger for migraines. Other common triggers include stress, certain foods, and hormonal changes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Tension headache: This type of headache is usually bilateral, non-pulsatile, and described as a band-like tightness around the head. It does not typically present with photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.
  • • Option B. Tension headache:
  • • Option C. Cluster headache: Cluster headaches are characterized by severe, unilateral pain around the eye, often accompanied by autonomic symptoms such as tearing, nasal congestion, and redness of the eye. They do not typically involve photophobia, phonophobia, or nausea.
  • • Option C. Cluster headache:
  • • Option D. Malingering: This refers to the intentional production of false or grossly exaggerated physical or psychological symptoms, motivated by external incentives such as avoiding work or obtaining drugs. There is no indication in the question to suggest malingering.
  • • Option D. Malingering:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Migraine is characterized by unilateral, pulsatile headaches accompanied by photophobia, phonophobia, and nausea, and can be triggered by factors such as skipping meals, stress, and certain foods. Recognizing these features is crucial for accurate diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: 52-year-old man collapses and you are giving CPR with your friend. What is the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 30:2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In adult CPR, the ratio of chest compressions to rescue breaths is always 30:2, regardless of the number of rescuers.

questions.text: All are components of CURB65 except? (AIIMS MAY 2017)

options.label: D
options.text: Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg

questions.correct_answer: D. Systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Systolic blood pressure less than 10mm Hg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ CURB-65 scoring system is used to evaluate pneumonia severity, which does not include systolic blood pressure less than 100 mm Hg but instead sets the threshold at ≤90 mm Hg systolic or ≤60 mm Hg diastolic.

questions.text: Which of the following is the least common cause of bipedal edema? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Chronic Venous Insufficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic venous insufficiency typically causes unilateral or asymmetric leg swelling, making it the least common cause of symmetric bipedal edema.

questions.text: Mark the correct statement regarding inflammatory bowel disease (IBD): ( INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease

options.label: B
options.text: Mucosal layers are involved in Crohn's disease and transmural involvement is seen in ulcerative colitis

options.label: C
options.text: Inflammatory bowel disease has a strong genetic predisposition

options.label: D
options.text: Crohn's disease is curable through surgical resection of the affected segment

questions.correct_answer: A. Skepletions are present in Crohn's disease
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skepletions (skip lesions) are a characteristic feature of Crohn's disease, distinguishing it from ulcerative colitis

questions.text: A patient on anti-tubercular therapy develops tingling sensation in the limbs. Which of the following when substituted can result from in improvement of symptoms? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyridoxine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyridoxine (vitamin B6) supplementation is essential for patients receiving isoniazid as part of their anti-tubercular therapy to prevent or manage peripheral neuropathy symptoms.

questions.text: Binswanger's disease, a form of vascular dementia, primarily affects which part of the brain? (NEET PG 2015)

options.label: C
options.text: Both the white and gray matter

options.label: D
options.text: Neither the white nor the gray matter

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Binswanger's disease, also known as subcortical arteriosclerotic encephalopathy, is a prototypical clinical syndrome of vascular cognitive impairment that primarily affects the white matter of the brain. The condition is characterized by progressive confluent subcortical and periventricular white matter disease visible on neuroimaging, with hypoperfusion and hypometabolism. Pathologically, it involves extensive demyelination and destruction of white matter with relative sparing of the subcortical U fibers. Patients typically present with hypertension or systemic vascular disease, and may develop gradual accumulation of focal neurological deficits along with cognitive dysfunction.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. The gray matter: Binswanger's disease specifically targets white matter rather than gray matter. Gray matter disorders typically present with different clinical patterns, such as cortical symptoms including aphasia, agnosia, or apraxia, which are not characteristic of Binswanger's disease.
  • • Option B. The gray matter:
  • • Option C. Both the white and gray matter: While some vascular dementias can affect both white and gray matter, Binswanger's disease is defined by its predominant impact on white matter. The pathology shows selective destruction of white matter with relative preservation of gray matter structures.
  • • Option C. Both the white and gray matter:
  • • Option D. Neither the white nor the gray matter: This is incorrect as Binswanger's disease definitively affects brain tissue, specifically the white matter regions. It is not a disease of other tissues such as blood vessels alone or non-neural brain components.
  • • Option D. Neither the white nor the gray matter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Binswanger's disease is a subcortical vascular dementia characterized by progressive white matter destruction due to small vessel disease, resulting in a dysexecutive syndrome with apathy, mood alterations, executive dysfunction, and slowed information processing.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presents with acute pain and swelling of the right knee. Synovial fluid analysis shows rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. Lab investigations show normal serum uric acid levels. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Pseudogout

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pseudogout (calcium pyrophosphate deposition disease, CPPD) is characterized by the deposition of calcium pyrophosphate dihydrate crystals in the joints. Key features include:
  • • Pseudogout
  • • Acute pain and swelling of the knee: The knee is the most commonly affected joint in pseudogout, unlike gout which frequently involves the first MTP joint. Synovial fluid findings: Rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy confirm the diagnosis. Normal serum uric acid levels: This differentiates pseudogout from gout.
  • • Acute pain and swelling of the knee: The knee is the most commonly affected joint in pseudogout, unlike gout which frequently involves the first MTP joint.
  • • Acute pain and swelling of the knee:
  • • Synovial fluid findings: Rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals under polarized light microscopy confirm the diagnosis.
  • • Synovial fluid findings:
  • • Normal serum uric acid levels: This differentiates pseudogout from gout.
  • • Normal serum uric acid levels:
  • • Pseudogout is more common in elderly patients but can also occur in middle-aged individuals, especially in the context of metabolic disorders or alcohol use.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Acute gout: Incorrect because gout is characterized by monosodium urate crystals, which are needle-shaped and negatively birefringent, and it commonly affects the first MTP joint rather than the knee.
  • • Option B. Acute gout:
  • • Option C. Reactive arthritis: Incorrect because this condition typically follows gastrointestinal or genitourinary infections and is associated with asymmetrical polyarthritis, often involving the lower extremities, along with other features like conjunctivitis or urethritis.
  • • Option C. Reactive arthritis:
  • • Option D. Septic arthritis: Incorrect because septic arthritis usually presents with systemic symptoms like fever, marked leukocytosis, and more severe joint destruction. The presence of crystals in the synovial fluid strongly suggests a crystal-induced arthropathy, not septic arthritis.
  • • Option D. Septic arthritis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pseudogout is characterized by acute joint pain and swelling, most commonly affecting the knee, with synovial fluid findings of rhomboid-shaped, positively birefringent crystals. Differentiation from gout and septic arthritis is critical for appropriate management.

questions.text: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acute Kidney Injury (AKI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The AKIN and RIFLE criteria are essential tools for diagnosing and assessing the severity of Acute Kidney Injury, which can guide interventions and predict outcomes in affected patients. They emphasize changes in serum creatinine and urine output as key indicators of kidney function.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presented with recurrent pulmonary infections and bulky greasy stools. Quantitative estimation of the stool fat was more than 10g/day. Which of the following will be seen in this child? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Distal intestinal obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In children with cystic fibrosis, recurrent pulmonary infections and steatorrhea are common, and one of the significant gastrointestinal complications is distal intestinal obstruction syndrome (DIOS). This condition should be considered in CF patients presenting with symptoms of intestinal obstruction.

questions.text: The patient is having the following hand movements. Which of the following conditions is responsible? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypercarbia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The hand movements shown in the image are characteristic of asterixis or flapping tremors, which is a form of negative myoclonus.
  • • Asterixis is most commonly associated with hepatic encephalopathy but can also be seen in other conditions such as hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis).
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Thyrotoxicosis: This condition typically presents with fine tremors rather than the flapping tremors seen in asterixis.
  • • Option A. Thyrotoxicosis:
  • • Option C. Hemiballismus: This condition involves violent, involuntary movements of one side of the body, not the flapping tremors associated with asterixis.
  • • Option C. Hemiballismus:
  • • Option D. Hypoxia: While hypoxia can cause various neurological symptoms, it is not specifically associated with asterixis.
  • • Option D. Hypoxia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Asterixis, or flapping tremors, is a form of negative myoclonus often associated with hepatic encephalopathy and hypercarbia (CO2 narcosis). Recognizing these characteristic hand movements can help identify underlying conditions such as hypercarbia. ​

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Subarachnoid hemorrhage presents with sudden, severe headache, nuchal rigidity, and hypertension. CT scan shows blood in the subarachnoid space, appearing as a "star of death."

questions.text: A chronic smoker presents with weight gain and hyperpigmentation. High dose dexamethasone suppression test was done in a patient & ACTH remained high before and after the test. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ectopic ACTH producing tumor

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient is a chronic smoker, which increases the risk of cancers such as small cell lung cancer, known to produce ectopic ACTH. The presentation of weight gain and hyperpigmentation are features of Cushing's syndrome. In ectopic ACTH production, the high-dose dexamethasone suppression test typically fails to suppress ACTH levels, as observed in this patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pituitary adenoma: In Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary adenoma, ACTH levels usually decrease with high-dose dexamethasone suppression.
  • • Option A. Pituitary adenoma:
  • • Option C. Exogenous source: Exogenous steroids do not cause hyperpigmentation and would suppress ACTH levels.
  • • Option C. Exogenous source:
  • • Option D. Adrenal adenoma: In adrenal adenoma, cortisol levels are high, which suppresses ACTH production, leading to low ACTH levels and no hyperpigmentation.
  • • Option D. Adrenal adenoma:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ectopic ACTH production, often from small cell lung cancer, should be suspected in chronic smokers presenting with features of Cushing's syndrome and non-suppressible ACTH levels following high-dose dexamethasone suppression test. ​

questions.text: The flow volume curve after spirometry in patient 1 is given below. The most likely diagnosis in this patient is? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Myasthenia gravis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia gravis can present with a restrictive pattern on pulmonary function tests due to respiratory muscle weakness, differentiating it from conditions that cause obstructive patterns such as asthma and emphysema.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH)? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urinary sodium <20 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The key fact to remember is that in SIADH, patients have high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L) due to the body's inability to excrete water properly, leading to concentrated urine.
  • ➤ high urinary sodium (typically >40 mEq/L)

questions.text: Dialysis disequilibrium occurs due to:(NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reverse urea effect

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is characterized by neurologic symptoms of varying severity, primarily due to cerebral edema. This condition is most commonly attributed to the "reverse urea effect." During hemodialysis, urea is removed from the blood more quickly than from the brain, creating an osmotic gradient. This causes water to flow into the brain, leading to cerebral edema and increased intracranial pressure. Symptoms of DDS include headache, nausea, vomiting, blurred vision, muscle twitching, disorientation, delirium, hypertension, tremors, and seizures. The condition is typically self-limiting and improves with time.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Hypertension: Although hypertension can be a complication of dialysis, it is not the primary cause of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.
  • • Option B. Hypertension:
  • • Option C. Aluminum toxicity: Aluminum toxicity can cause encephalopathy in dialysis patients, but it is not related to the acute neurologic symptoms seen in dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.
  • • Option C. Aluminum toxicity:
  • • Option D. Amyloid deposition: Amyloid deposition occurs in long-term dialysis patients and can lead to dialysis-related amyloidosis, but it is not responsible for the acute symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium syndrome.
  • • Option D. Amyloid deposition:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome occurs primarily due to the "reverse urea effect," where a rapid reduction of urea in the blood during dialysis creates an osmotic gradient, leading to water influx into the brain and subsequent cerebral edema.

questions.text: Which among the following according to the latest guidelines is NOT an indication to IE prophylaxis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Atrial Septal Defect (ASD) is not an indication for infective endocarditis prophylaxis according to the latest guidelines, whereas prior infective endocarditis, prosthetic valves, cardiac transplant with valvulopathy, and certain congenital heart diseases are key indications.

questions.text: 65-year-old lady with a history of COPD and cor pulmonale presents with breathlessness and frequent exacerbations. Which of the following will improve survival in this patient? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Long-term O2 therapy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-term oxygen therapy (LTOT) is one of the few interventions that improve survival in patients with COPD, especially those with severe hypoxemia and complications like cor pulmonale.

questions.text: What does the Red Cell Distribution Width (RDW) measure? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anisocytosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ RDW measures the variability in size of red blood cells, which is indicative of anisocytosis. High RDW is associated with conditions like iron deficiency anemia and other types of anemia, where there is significant variation in RBC sizes.
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ Additional Information
  • ➤ IDA vs Thalassemia
  • ➤ IDA vs Thalassemia
  • ➤ IDA- rbcs are small (low MCV ) with high RDW
  • ➤ Thalassemia- RBCs are small (low MCV ) with normal RDW

questions.text: A 54-year-old male recently underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). Within a few days after taking a saphenous vein graft, he complained of pain in the legs, and on examination, he had mild sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot on the side from where the graft was harvested. What is the nerve likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Saphenous nerve

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The saphenous nerve, due to its proximity to the saphenous vein, is at risk of injury during saphenous vein harvesting for CABG, leading to sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. CXR shows a 3 cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung. What is the next best step for the management of this patient? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a patient with a significant smoking history and a peripheral lung mass larger than 2 cm, a CT guided biopsy is the next best step to diagnose the nature of the mass.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient has NYHA class III heart failure, with dyspnea, pedal edema and K+ levels of 5.5mg% and creatinine 1.1 mg%. Which of the following drugs can be used in this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Furosemide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In heart failure patients with elevated potassium levels, loop diuretics like furosemide are preferred to manage fluid overload and avoid exacerbation of hyperkalemia, unlike potassium-sparing diuretics or ACE inhibitors.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia, eczema and recurrent infections are seen in: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome is distinguished by its symptom triad of thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections, directly related to mutations in the WASP gene affecting cellular function and immune response. Understanding these features is critical in diagnosing the syndrome and managing its complex clinical manifestations effectively.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Immunodeficiencies/Chapter 351,374

questions.text: A patient with CKD with refractory hypertension is brought to the casualty with dizziness. His BP was found to be 200/120 mmHg. His BUN was 50 mg/dl and creatinine was 3 mg/dl. Potassium was 6 mEq/L. Which of the following is an indication of emergency hemodialysis? ( INICET Nov 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

questions.correct_answer: A. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Emergency hemodialysis is indicated for severe acidosis, refractory hyperkalemia, volume overload, intoxications, and uremic complications. Severe acidosis with elevated BUN and creatinine is a critical indication for initiating emergency hemodialysis.

questions.text: Bilateral upper limb pulseless disease is?( NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Takayasu arteritis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Takayasu arteritis, also known as ‘Aorto-Arteritis’, is a form of large vessel granulomatous vasculitis characterized by massive intimal fibrosis and vascular narrowing. It is known as the "pulseless disease" due to the obstruction of the main branches of the aorta, including the brachiocephalic artery on the right and the subclavian and common carotid arteries on the left. This results in feeble or absent pulses in both upper extremities (bilateral upper limb pulseless disease).
  • • Takayasu Disease:
  • • Takayasu Disease:
  • • Pathophysiology: Involves all three layers of the arterial wall causing extensive intimal proliferation, inflammation of media and adventitia followed by marked fibrous scarring. Histology: Shows round cell infiltration, cuffing of vasa vasorum, and destruction of tunica media leading to gross fibrosis. Also Known As: ‘Aortic arch syndrome’, ‘non-specific aortoarteritis’, ‘pulseless disease’, and ‘reversed coarctation’. Clinical Presentation: Feeble or absent pulses in both upper extremities, hypertension (due to renal artery stenosis).
  • • Pathophysiology: Involves all three layers of the arterial wall causing extensive intimal proliferation, inflammation of media and adventitia followed by marked fibrous scarring.
  • • Histology: Shows round cell infiltration, cuffing of vasa vasorum, and destruction of tunica media leading to gross fibrosis.
  • • Also Known As: ‘Aortic arch syndrome’, ‘non-specific aortoarteritis’, ‘pulseless disease’, and ‘reversed coarctation’.
  • • Clinical Presentation: Feeble or absent pulses in both upper extremities, hypertension (due to renal artery stenosis).
  • • Comparison:
  • • Comparison:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Giant Cell Arteritis: Typically affects the temporal arteries and does not cause bilateral upper limb pulseless disease.
  • • Option A. Giant Cell Arteritis:
  • • Option B. Polyarteritis Nodosa: Affects medium-sized arteries and does not commonly present with bilateral upper limb pulseless disease.
  • • Option B. Polyarteritis Nodosa:
  • • Option D. Coarctation of Aorta: Causes diminished pulses in the lower extremities, not the upper limbs.
  • • Option D. Coarctation of Aorta:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Takayasu arteritis is characterized by diminished or absent pulses in both upper extremities, earning it the name "pulseless disease"

questions.text: Many GPCR receptors act via an increase in cAMP. The steps involved in this mechanism are given below. Which of the following is the correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway? (INICET MAY 2024) Activation of adenylate cyclase Activation of PKA Conversion of ATP to cAMP Phosphorylation of target proteins
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1, 3, 2 and 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence of events in the cAMP signal transduction pathway activated by G-stimulatory GPCRs is: Activation of adenylate cyclase, conversion of ATP to cAMP, activation of PKA, and phosphorylation of target proteins.

questions.text: A 52-year-old lady develops sudden onset facial deviation with slurring of speech and inability to raise right arm. The symptoms spontaneously begin to reduce and has significant improvement over the next 48 hours. She has a mid-diastolic murmur on auscultation and irregular heart rhythm. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cardio-embolic stroke

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The patient presents with sudden onset neurological deficits (facial deviation, slurred speech, and right arm weakness), which improved significantly over 48 hours. The presence of a mid-diastolic murmur suggests mitral stenosis, and the irregular heart rhythm indicates atrial fibrillation. These are strong risk factors for cardio-embolic stroke. Although the improvement suggests a transient ischemic attack (TIA), the symptoms lasted more than 24 hours, which aligns with the definition of a stroke rather than a TIA.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. TIA: By definition, a TIA's symptoms resolve within 24 hours. Since the symptoms persisted for more than 24 hours, this is not a TIA.
  • • Option A. TIA:
  • • within 24 hours.
  • • Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke: While possible, the presence of mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation makes cardio-embolic stroke more likely.
  • • Option B. Thrombo-embolic stroke:
  • • Option D. Paradoxical embolism: This occurs when a thrombus from the venous system passes through a right-to-left cardiac shunt (e.g., patent foramen ovale) into the arterial system. There is no mention of such a shunt or a history of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in this case.
  • • Option D. Paradoxical embolism:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cardio-embolic stroke should be suspected in patients with sudden onset neurological deficits and risk factors such as mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation. Symptoms persisting for more than 24 hours distinguish stroke from TIA.

questions.text: A child presents to the emergency department with a history of ingestion of multiple copper sulfate tablets. Arterial blood gas reveals metabolic acidosis and serum copper levels are elevated. Which of the following can be used in the management of this condition? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Dimercaprol

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Copper sulfate poisoning can cause gastrointestinal irritation, hemolysis, hepatotoxicity, and metabolic acidosis. Elevated serum copper levels confirm systemic toxicity. The management includes:
  • • Copper sulfate poisoning
  • • Dimercaprol: A chelating agent that binds copper, reducing its toxicity and promoting excretion. It is the primary treatment for acute copper poisoning. Supportive care to manage complications such as acidosis and dehydration.
  • • Dimercaprol: A chelating agent that binds copper, reducing its toxicity and promoting excretion. It is the primary treatment for acute copper poisoning.
  • • Dimercaprol:
  • • Supportive care to manage complications such as acidosis and dehydration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Whole Bowel Irrigation: Incorrect because WBI is more effective in managing ingestion of substances that are visible on abdominal X-ray (e.g., iron tablets) but is not the primary treatment for systemic copper toxicity.
  • • Option A. Whole Bowel Irrigation:
  • • Option B. Activated Charcoal: Incorrect because activated charcoal does not adsorb metals like copper, iron, or lead, making it ineffective in copper sulfate poisoning.
  • • Option B. Activated Charcoal:
  • • Option D. Deferoxamine: Incorrect because deferoxamine is specific for iron poisoning and has no chelating action against copper.
  • • Option D. Deferoxamine:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dimercaprol is the chelating agent of choice for acute copper poisoning. Prompt recognition and treatment are critical to prevent severe complications such as hemolysis and multiorgan failure. Whole bowel irrigation and activated charcoal are not effective for heavy metal poisoning.

questions.text: A 30-year-old HIV-positive man presents with fever for 3 weeks, dry cough, and significant weight loss. His HRCT thorax is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/HIV/Opportunistic Infection in HIV/Chap

questions.text: A 38-year-old man collapsed and was brought to the emergency. ECG was taken and a diagnosis of atrial fibrillation (AF) was made. Which of the following is true? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Almost never seen in heart with normal morphology

options.label: B
options.text: IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control

options.label: C
options.text: DC Cardioversion is required in all cases

options.label: D
options.text: Discrepancy in HR and PR is a clinically reliable criteria for diagnosis

questions.correct_answer: B. IV Digoxin can be used for ventricular rate control
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ IV Digoxin can be effectively used for ventricular rate control in patients with atrial fibrillation, especially in those with heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of hypercalcemia due to Vitamin D toxicity? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Dexamethasone, Bisphosphonates, IV fluids, Loop diuretics, Calcitonin are used in the management of Hypercalcemia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - (Harrison/Endocrinology/Hypercalcemia)

questions.text: A patient with renal failure develops vomiting in ICU. ABG analysis showed pH - 7.4, Na+ = 145 mEq/L, Cl- = 100 mEq/L, HC03- = 24mEq/L, PaC02 = 40 mmHg. What is the likely metabolic abnormality? (AIIMS NOV 2019)

options.label: C
options.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

options.label: D
options.text: High anion gap metabolic alkalosis with normal metabolic acidosis

questions.correct_answer: C. High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis
questions.explanation:
Ans. C)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In patients with renal failure and symptoms like vomiting, it's crucial to evaluate both the anion gap and changes in bicarbonate to identify complex acid-base disturbances such as the coexistence of high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic smoker presented with mild recurrent hemoptysis without fever or weight loss. The chest X-ray appears normal and the sputum is negative for AFB. Which of the following is the most useful diagnostic investigation? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) CT Thorax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The choice of CT Thorax (HRCT or CECT) is critical for early detection of potential malignancies or other significant lung conditions in a high-risk individual, particularly when initial less sensitive tests like chest X-ray and sputum analysis have failed to elucidate the cause of symptoms.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - (Harrison 21E, 597,598) Resp Med/Hemoptysis/Lung CA

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presented with arthritis. She had a history of fever and sore throat 1 week ago. On examination, you hear a pansystolic murmur suggestive of mitral regurgitation. What is the finding you will see in the biopsy? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Aschoff nodule

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with a history of sore throat followed by symptoms such as arthritis and carditis, acute rheumatic fever should be considered. The presence of Aschoff nodules in biopsy is pathognomonic for this condition, confirming the diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Reduced serum iron level 2.Reduced transferrin saturation 3.Increased total iron binding capacity 4.Reduced ferritin level
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron deficiency anemia involves reduced serum iron, reduced transferrin saturation, increased TIBC, and reduced ferritin levels

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman presents with a progressive decline in daily activity. She gives a history of staring into space with frequent visual hallucinations. Pathology reveals Lewy bodies in neurons. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Parkinson’s Disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Lewy bodies in neurons and clinical features such as visual hallucinations and progressive decline in activity are indicative of Parkinson’s disease.

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ventricular diastole

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aortic regurgitation murmurs are heard during ventricular diastole

questions.text: A patient presents to you with fatigue, malaise, and no jaundice. What is the most likely diagnosis based on the serology reports given below? (Twisted PYQ) Anti-HBc (IgM): Negative Anti-HBc (IgG): Positive HBsAg: Positive Anti-HBs: Negative Anti-HCV antibodies: Negative
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Chronic hepatitis B

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Chronic hepatitis B is diagnosed based on the persistence of HBsAg for more than six months along with the presence of IgG anti-HBc (indicating past exposure). The absence of IgM anti-HBc confirms that this is not an acute infection. Additional serologic markers support this diagnosis:
  • • Chronic hepatitis B
  • • HBsAg
  • • IgG anti-HBc
  • • IgM anti-HBc
  • • HBsAg positive: Indicates ongoing infection. IgG anti-HBc positive: Reflects prior exposure to the hepatitis B virus. Anti-HBs negative: Suggests that immunity has not been achieved (either naturally or through vaccination).
  • • HBsAg positive: Indicates ongoing infection.
  • • HBsAg positive:
  • • IgG anti-HBc positive: Reflects prior exposure to the hepatitis B virus.
  • • IgG anti-HBc positive:
  • • Anti-HBs negative: Suggests that immunity has not been achieved (either naturally or through vaccination).
  • • Anti-HBs negative:
  • • Chronic hepatitis B may present without overt symptoms such as jaundice and can remain asymptomatic or progress to complications such as cirrhosis or hepatocellular carcinoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute hepatitis B: Incorrect because IgM anti-HBc is negative, ruling out acute infection. Acute hepatitis B is characterized by positive HBsAg and IgM anti-HBc .
  • • Option A. Acute hepatitis B:
  • • IgM anti-HBc
  • • IgM anti-HBc
  • • Option C. Resolved hepatitis B infection: Incorrect because in resolved infection, HBsAg is negative and anti-HBs is positive , indicating immunity.
  • • Option C. Resolved hepatitis B infection:
  • • HBsAg is negative
  • • anti-HBs is positive
  • • Option D. Acute hepatitis C: Incorrect because anti-HCV antibodies are negative, ruling out hepatitis C as the cause of the symptoms.
  • • Option D. Acute hepatitis C:
  • • anti-HCV antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic hepatitis B is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg and the presence of IgG anti-HBc. Differentiating acute from chronic hepatitis B is critical for appropriate management and long-term monitoring to prevent complications like cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma.

questions.text: Which of the following disease pathogenesis primarily involves the marked structure: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Paralysis agitans

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The substantia nigra's degeneration is central to the pathogenesis of Parkinson's disease, manifesting as motor symptoms like bradykinesia, stiffness, and resting tremors.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient with critical mitral stenosis presented with atrial fibrillation. He has a history of multiple episodes of transient ischemic attacks. Which of the following are true regarding the prevention of stroke in this patient? (INICET NOV 2021) Only aspirin is given Warfarin is given Direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated Mitral valvotomy should be recommended
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with critical mitral stenosis and atrial fibrillation, especially those with a history of TIA, Warfarin should be given for stroke prevention, and direct oral anticoagulants are not indicated.

questions.text: A patient following a road traffic accident presented with subcutaneous emphysema, respiratory distress, and hypotension. On auscultation, there was no air entry on the right side and a hyper-resonant note was felt on percussion. X-ray is shown. What will be your immediate management? (FMGE JULY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

questions.correct_answer: A. Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate management for tension pneumothorax is needle thoracostomy in the 5th intercostal space in the mid-axillary line, followed by the insertion of a chest drain.

questions.text: A female patient with infertility presents with galactorrhea. Evaluation reveals a 7mm prolactinoma. She reports experiencing significant nausea and dizziness after starting initial therapy with cabergoline. What is the appropriate drug in this situation? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Bromocriptine

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • When a patient with a prolactinoma cannot tolerate cabergoline due to adverse effects such as significant nausea and dizziness, Bromocriptine serves as an effective alternative. Bromocriptine is a dopamine receptor agonist like cabergoline but is generally better tolerated in some patients. It helps reduce prolactin levels, shrink the prolactinoma, and restore fertility by decreasing prolactin secretion and normalizing gonadal function.
  • • Bromocriptine
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Cabergoline: Incorrect because the patient is experiencing adverse effects from cabergoline, making it unsuitable as the continued treatment option.
  • • Option A. Cabergoline:
  • • Option C. Octreotide: Incorrect because octreotide is a somatostatin analog primarily used for treating acromegaly and certain types of tumors, not prolactinomas. It does not effectively reduce prolactin levels in prolactinoma patients.
  • • Option C. Octreotide:
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant: Incorrect because pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used in the treatment of acromegaly and has no role in managing prolactinomas or hyperprolactinemia.
  • • Option D. Pegvisomant:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with prolactinomas who experience intolerance or adverse effects from cabergoline, bromocriptine is an appropriate alternative dopamine receptor agonist. Both medications are effective in reducing prolactin levels, shrinking prolactinomas, and restoring fertility. Understanding the side effect profiles and alternative treatment options is crucial for managing patients effectively.

questions.text: Regarding tumor lysis syndrome, which of the following is NOT a typical laboratory finding?(NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Elevated calcium levels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Tumor lysis syndrome (TLS) is characterized by hypocalcemia (low calcium), not elevated calcium. This occurs due to reciprocal depression of serum calcium in response to hyperphosphatemia, which results from massive tumor cell breakdown and release of intracellular phosphate. The hypocalcemia can cause severe neuromuscular irritability and tetany. Additionally, calcium phosphate deposition in the kidneys can contribute to renal failure.
  • • hypocalcemia
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Elevated potassium levels: Hyperkalemia is a hallmark finding in TLS. Potassium is the principal intracellular cation, and massive destruction of malignant cells leads to hyperkalemia. This electrolyte abnormality in patients with renal failure may rapidly become life threatening by causing ventricular arrhythmias and sudden death.
  • • Option A. Elevated potassium levels:
  • • Option C. Elevated uric acid levels: Hyperuricemia is a characteristic finding of TLS. Effective treatment kills malignant cells and leads to increased serum uric acid levels from the turnover of nucleic acids. Uric acid can precipitate in the renal tubules, leading to renal failure.
  • • Option C. Elevated uric acid levels:
  • • Option D. Elevated phosphate levels: Hyperphosphatemia is typical in TLS. The release of intracellular phosphate pools by tumor lysis produces a reciprocal depression in serum calcium.
  • • Option D. Elevated phosphate levels:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tumor lysis syndrome presents with a characteristic tetrad of laboratory abnormalities:
  • ➤ along with potential development of acute renal failure. The hypocalcemia is a consequence of hyperphosphatemia due to the inverse relationship between serum phosphate and calcium levels.

questions.text: Osborn waves in ECG are seen in: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hypothermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ J-wave or Osborn wave is seen in cases of moderate or severe hypothermia due to increase in the epicardial potassium current relative to that of endocardium during ventricular repolarization.
  • ➤ moderate or severe hypothermia
  • ➤ increase in the epicardial potassium current

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown-Séquard syndrome? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.correct_answer: A. Complete transection of spinal cord
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Complete transection of spinal cord

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Brown-Séquard syndrome is characterized by hemisection of the spinal cord, leading to ipsilateral loss of vibration, touch, and proprioception, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature. Complete transection of the spinal cord is not a feature of this syndrome

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presented with diarrhea and intolerance to dairy products. On investigation, he was found to have a lactase deficiency. Which of the following agents is least likely to cause symptoms of lactose intolerance? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Yogurt

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Yogurt contains lactobacillus, that helps in lactase production and also low lactose levels.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Gastroenterology/Diarrhea/chap 471

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Anti HBs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anti-HBs antibodies indicate recovery and immunity from hepatitis B infection. This is the only protective antibody that signifies the patient has successfully recovered from the infection and has developed immunity.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male patient came to ED with complaints of weakness, paresthesia, and breathing difficulty. Relevant investigations were done. The ECG obtained is suggestive of: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Hypokalemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ECG Findings in Hypokalemia :
  • ➤ ECG Findings in Hypokalemia
  • ➤ U-waves Prolonged QTc Flattened/inverted Ts Sagging ST ST Depression Biphasic t-waves ST elevation in aVR PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias Pseudo-ischemic patterns
  • ➤ U-waves
  • ➤ Prolonged QTc
  • ➤ Flattened/inverted Ts
  • ➤ Sagging ST
  • ➤ ST Depression
  • ➤ Biphasic t-waves
  • ➤ ST elevation in aVR
  • ➤ PVCs/Ventricular Dysrhythmias
  • ➤ Pseudo-ischemic patterns

questions.text: A diabetic nephropathy patient is an ideal candidate for renal graft transplant. Which of the following statements is true? (AIIMS MAY 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: The survival rate of graft is 95% in the first year

options.label: B
options.text: The life expectancy is doubled in a diabetic patient with renal transplant

options.label: C
options.text: The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

options.label: D
options.text: The treatment of chronic rejection has improved over the last 10 years

questions.correct_answer: C. The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The transplantation is cost effective after the second transplant year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Renal transplantation becomes cost-effective after the second year post-transplant for diabetic nephropathy patients compared to ongoing dialysis. This consideration, coupled with improved quality of life and potential prolongation of life expectancy, makes it a favorable option for suitable candidates.

questions.text: An elderly woman presents with a chronic history of pain in the small joints of hands with stiffness of joints in the early hours of the day. The image of the patient's hands is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rheumatoid Arthritis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rheumatoid Arthritis is suggested by the presence of symmetrical small joint pain and stiffness, particularly in the morning, with potential visible joint deformities. Early and aggressive treatment is vital to manage symptoms and prevent progressive joint damage.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a penicillin allergy presents with enterococcal endocarditis. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in this patient? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with penicillin allergies who have enterococcal infections, vancomycin is the preferred and safe alternative for treatment.

questions.text: A 13-year-old boy collapsed while playing football. ECG showed V5, V6 inversion and prominent inverted T-waves. 2D echocardiography showed the septal anterior motion of mitral valve leaflet. Which of the following features will be seen on clinical examination and which of the following are true regarding the management? (INICET NOV 2020) Clinical findings a. Pulsus bisferiens b. Pulsus alternans c. Ejection systolic murmur d. Murmur increases on standing e. Murmur decreases on standing Management 1. Beta-blockers are given 2. Beta-blockers are contraindicated 3. ICD is indicated 4. ICD is contraindicated
questions.explanation:
Ans. A)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ Key Points:
  • ➤ All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • ➤ All murmurs decrease on standing except MVP and HCM.
  • ➤ Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • ➤ Pulsus bisferiens can be seen in HCM
  • ➤ HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • ➤ HCM is characterized by myocyte disarray & fibrosis causing increase risk of sudden cardiac death & arrhythmias.
  • ➤ Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF
  • ➤ Pulsus alternans is seen in LVF

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Basics of CVS/Chap 239

questions.text: Chronic HBV infection would be consistent with which of the following serology? ( INICET MAY 2022) HBsAg Anti-HBsAg Anti-HBcAg HBV DNA
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chronic HBV infection is characterized by the persistence of HBsAg, the presence of Anti-HBc, and usually detectable HBV DNA. Anti-HBs is not present in chronic HBV infection as it indicates immunity.

questions.text: The antibodies typically elevated in primary biliary cirrhosis are? (NEET PG 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Anti-mitochondrial antibodies

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Anti-mitochondrial antibodies (AMA) are the hallmark serological marker for primary biliary cirrhosis (now termed primary biliary cholangitis). These antibodies are highly specific, with >95% of patients having AMA directed against the PDC-E2 pattern. The presence of these antibodies, along with elevated IgM levels and compatible histology, represents the classic diagnostic triad for this condition.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Anti-actin antibodies : These antibodies (smooth muscle antibodies) are characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis type I, not primary biliary cholangitis. Smooth muscle antibodies (SMA) are typically seen in autoimmune hepatitis along with antinuclear antibodies.
  • • Option A. Anti-actin antibodies
  • • Option B. Antinuclear antibodies : While antinuclear antibodies may be present in some patients with primary biliary cholangitis, they are more characteristic of autoimmune hepatitis type I, particularly with a homogeneous pattern.
  • • Option B. Antinuclear antibodies
  • • Option D. Anti-soluble liver antigen antibodies : These antibodies are associated with autoimmune hepatitis type III, not primary biliary cholangitis. Anti-SLA serves as a marker for this subtype of autoimmune hepatitis.
  • • Option D. Anti-soluble liver antigen antibodies

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Primary biliary cholangitis (formerly called primary biliary cirrhosis) has a highly specific serological marker - anti-mitochondrial antibodies - which are found in >95% of patients and target the PDC-E2 pattern, making them a valuable diagnostic tool for this condition.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presents with complaints of dryness in the mouth and eyes. She also has dysphagia. On examination, dental caries and enlarged cervical lymph nodes are noted. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sjogren syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sjogren syndrome is characterized by dry mouth, dry eyes, dysphagia, dental caries, and lymphadenopathy, due to autoimmune destruction of exocrine glands.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man presents to the emergency department with respiratory distress and hypotension following a trauma. He has subcutaneous emphysema and there is an absence of air entry into the right side of the lungs. What is the next best step? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Start IV fluids with large bore cannula

options.label: B
options.text: Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

options.label: C
options.text: Take the patient to the ICU and intubate

questions.correct_answer: B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Needle decompression into the 5th intercostal space anterior to the midaxillary line

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of tension pneumothorax, immediate needle decompression is critical to stabilize the patient and prevent further cardiovascular compromise. This emergency procedure is a life-saving intervention that precedes further definitive management like chest tube insertion.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Pneumothorax/ Chap 294

questions.text: A patient has right upper limb BP of >180/95 mmHg and a left upper limb BP of 130/90 mmHg. He also has early diastolic murmur in right 2 nd intercostal space. Which of the following is least likely to be associated with these findings? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While differential arm blood pressure can suggest several cardiovascular anomalies, supravalvular aortic stenosis is least likely among the options given to be associated with these findings, especially concerning the presence of a diastolic murmur indicative of aortic regurgitation.

questions.text: A patient presents with a regular pulse of 60/minute and episodes of syncope. On examination, there is a regular pulse with intermittent loss of atrial contraction. Which of the following would be the JVP finding? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Cannon a waves in the jugular venous pulse (JVP) are indicative of atrioventricular (AV) dissociation, where the atria and ventricles contract independently of each other. This can occur in conditions such as complete heart block or ventricular tachycardia. The intermittent loss of atrial contraction relative to ventricular contraction leads to simultaneous atrial and ventricular systole, causing the atria to contract against a closed tricuspid valve. This results in the characteristic large, abrupt "a" waves known as Cannon a waves.
  • • Cannon a waves
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Absent p wave: Incorrect because absent p waves are an ECG finding associated with atrial fibrillation, not a specific JVP finding.
  • • Option A. Absent p wave:
  • • Option B. Absent a wave: Incorrect because absent a waves are typically seen in atrial fibrillation, where there is no coordinated atrial contraction, not in AV dissociation scenarios.
  • • Option B. Absent a wave:
  • • Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform: Incorrect because raised JVP can occur in various conditions such as heart failure, but a normal waveform would not explain the presence of Cannon a waves, which are specific to AV dissociation.
  • • Option D. Raised JVP with normal waveform:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cannon a waves in the jugular venous pulse are a key clinical sign of atrioventricular (AV) dissociation, such as in complete heart block or ventricular tachycardia. Recognizing these waves aids in diagnosing underlying cardiac arrhythmias that disrupt the normal coordination between atrial and ventricular contractions.
